citeinfo.origin: National Data Buoy Center (NDBC), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
citeinfo.title: National Data Buoy Center Moored Buoys and C-MAN Stations

abstract.p: Oceanographic and meteorological observations from moored buoys and onshore/nearshore platforms (Coastal-Marine Automated Network (C-MAN) stations). Most of the stations are located in the coastal and offshore waters of the U.S. The real-time data is often incorporated into other observing system networks on a regional or local basis. The state of Alaska has approximately five moored buoys and seven C-MAN stations. The states of Washington, Oregon, and the northern portion of California have approximately nine moored buoys and seven C-MAN stations. Central and southern California has approximately fifteen moored buoys and two C-MAN stations. The real-time data is often incorporated into other observing system networks on a regional or local basis. The state of Hawaii has approximately five moored buoys.

Observations include air temperature, dewpoint, sea level pressure, wind speed/direction, wind gust, visibility, current speed/direction, spectral wave density, spectral wave direction, directional wave spectrum, water level, sea surface temperature, average wave period, dominant wave period, and wave direction.

descript.purpose: To provide comprehensive, reliable systems and marine observations.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system. NOAA makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty.
